fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A sequence of functions \{f_n\} defined on a common domain D is said to converge uniformly to a function f on D if for every ε > 0, there exists an integer N(ε) (independent of x) such that:
|f_n(x) - f(x)| < ε for all x \in D and all n \geq N(ε)
In other words, the rate of convergence is uniform across all points in the domain. This is stronger than pointwise convergence, where the rate of convergence can vary from point to point.
Uniform convergence has several important properties:

fr:ul.fr:li: If each f_n is continuous and the sequence converges uniformly to f, then f is also continuous
If each f_n is integrable and the sequence converges uniformly to f, then \lim _{n \to \infty } \int _D f_n(x) dx = \int _D f(x) dx

If each f_n is differentiable and the sequence of derivatives \{f'_n\} converges uniformly, then the original sequence \{f_n\} converges uniformly to a differentiable function f, and f'(x) = \lim _{n \to \infty } f'_n(x)

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A common criterion for uniform convergence is the Weierstrass M-test, which states that if \{f_n\} is a sequence of functions satisfying |f_n(x)| \leq M_n for all x \in D, and if the series \sum _{n=1}^{\infty } M_n converges, then the series \sum _{n=1}^{\infty } f_n(x) converges uniformly on D.
A sequence of functions \{f_n\} defined on a common domain D is said to converge pointwise to a function f on D if for each x \in D, the sequence of numbers \{f_n(x)\} converges to f(x).
Formally, \{f_n\} converges pointwise to f if for every x \in D and every ε > 0, there exists an integer N(x,ε) such that:
|f_n(x) - f(x)| < ε for all n \geq N(x,ε)
Note that the integer N may depend on both x and ε, which is a key distinction from uniform convergence.

Pointwise convergence is generally weaker than uniform convergence. A sequence of functions can converge pointwise without preserving many important properties of the functions, such as continuity, boundedness, or integrability.
The Weierstrass M-test is a criterion for determining the uniform convergence of a series of functions. It states:
Let \{f_n\} be a sequence of functions defined on a common domain D, and let \{M_n\} be a sequence of non-negative real numbers such that:

fr:ol.fr:li: |f_n(x)| \leq M_n for all x \in D and all n \in \mathbb {N}

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Then the series \sum _{n=1}^{\infty } f_n(x) converges uniformly on D.

The Weierstrass M-test is particularly useful for establishing the uniform convergence of power series within their radius of convergence, as well as in various constructions involving function spaces.
Key implications of uniform convergence (which can often be established via the Weierstrass M-test) include:

fr:ul.fr:li: If each f_n is continuous and the series \sum f_n converges uniformly to f, then f is continuous
If each f_n is integrable and the series \sum f_n converges uniformly to f on [a,b], then \int _a^b f(x) dx = \sum _{n=1}^{\infty } \int _a^b f_n(x) dx
